Description: Ivory lion's head carved in very high relief. The back is flat with a rectangular mortise for attachment.
Curator's comments: It probably comes from a piece of furniture. In Egypt lions' heads sometimes appear at the front of thrones, as on the throne from the tomb of Tutan-khamun (Baker 1966: col. pl. VI) and this tradition might have passed into Phoenician art. On an Assyrian relief of Sargon a table is shown with lions' heads at the corners (Albenda 1986: pl. 50). Bibliography: R. D. Barnett, ‘A Catalogue of Nimrud Ivories in the British Museum’ (London, 1975), 235, Suppl. 32, pl. CXLI; P. Albenda, ‘The Palace of Sargon, King of Assyria’ (Paris, 1986); H. S. Baker, ‘Furniture in the Ancient World’ (London, 1966).
